title: Waste to Energy: Waste-to-Energy in a Circular Economy: Friend or Foe? | WMW - Waste Management World
summary: The European Union aims to reduce landfill waste and increase recycling rates. While waste-to-energy plants offer an alternative to landfills, experts stress the importance of efficient source separation to ensure recyclables don't end up in incinerators.  The article highlights the need for better sorting systems and legislation to regulate the flow of waste to ensure that waste-to-energy plants utilize only non-recyclable materials.

title: Enhancing waste resource efficiency: circular economy for sustainability and energy conversion - Frontiers
summary: This article discusses the Circular Economy (CE) framework and its application to waste management, particularly in Poland. The author analyzes the Orli Staw waste treatment plant, which utilizes a fermentation module to produce biogas from organic waste, showcasing the potential for waste to be a valuable resource. The article emphasizes the importance of prioritizing waste incineration plant design for quicker payback and explores other strategies to improve waste management efficiency, such as promoting sortable packaging and incentivizing sustainable sorting.

title: Meet Heinz Schandl: designing for zero waste - CSIRO

The program focuses on developing new products and services for materials that would normally go to waste, with a goal of achieving an 80% reduction in landfill waste by 2030. title: Scientific study finds remanufactured laptops produce only 6.34% of CO2 emissions in comparison to new ... - TECHNOLOGY RESELLER
summary: A peer-reviewed study by Cranfield University found that remanufactured laptops from Circular Computing produce only 6.34% of the CO2 emissions of new laptops, highlighting the environmental benefits of the circular economy. This remanufacturing process, which reuses 99% of existing technology, is a viable alternative to the ‘take, make and replace’ model of the tech industry, reducing e-waste and carbon footprint. The study reinforces the potential of remanufacturing to address the environmental concerns surrounding the tech industry.
